column1: Melchor de Eca y Múzquiz (5 January 1790 – 14 December 1844) was a Mexican soldier and politician. From August to December 1832
=== War of Independence and First Empire ===
Múzquiz was born on 6 April 1788 or sometime in March
column5: New Spain. He studied at the Colegio de San Ildefonso in Mexico City. While still a student
column6: he enlisted in the forces of General Ignacio López Rayón in 1810 in Coahuila to fight for Mexican independence from Spain. He took part in many engagements. In 1812
column8: he led the infantry in the defense of Zacapu. In November 1816
column10: he was taken prisoner at Fort Monteblanco
column12: Veracruz. He was freed under a general amnesty
column13: even though he refused to give his word that he would not fight again against the viceregal government of New Spain.

column3: he supported the Plan de Iguala
column4: which resulted in Agustín de Iturbide ascending the throne as Mexico's first emperor. However
column5: as a congressional deputy he did not support this result
column6: since he was a republican. He and other deputies proposed that Iturbide be declared a traitor. During the rebellion against the emperor

column2: he was supreme political chief of the Province of Mexico. On 2 March 1824
column3: the new Mexican Congress changed his title to governor of the State of Mexico. He returned for a second period as governor of the state from 26 April to 1 October 1830.

column1: He was also general of a division under President Guadalupe Victoria and military commandant of Puebla. In Puebla
column3: he rose against President Vicente Guerrero on 10 December 1828 (Plan de Jalapa). Múzquiz was initially defeated by José Joaquín de Herrera
column4: but the rebellion was successful. He was one of the individuals who offered the presidency to Anastasio Bustamante.

column2: when Antonio López de Santa Anna revolted
column3: President Bustamante left the capital to fight the rebels
column4: leaving Múzquiz as acting president (14 August 1832 to 26 December 1832). Neither Bustamante nor Santa Anna could prevail. Manuel Gómez Pedraza assumed the presidency on 24 December as the result of an agreement between the warring factions (Convenios de Zavaleta) and a congressional resolution

column1: Múzquiz was the first president to collect taxes on doors and windows.

column2: he was president of the Supremo Poder Conservador
column3: an institution of five members established under the Seven Laws with the power to dissolve Congress or the Supreme Court.He was a candidate for president in 1843
column4: but Santa Anna won the office. He died in December 1844
column6: remembered for his scrupulous honesty in the management of public funds. He was buried with full honors in the Cemetery of Santa Paula. Múzquiz was officially benemérito de la patria en grado heroico
